TITLE: Fed Officials Are on the Defensive as High Inflation Lingers
SUMMARY: Critics have accused the Federal Reserve of not reacting quickly enough to tame rising prices. On Friday, a Fed governor explained why it took so long.

TITLE: NLRB Finds Merit in Union Accusations Against Amazon and Starbucks
SUMMARY: Workers had accused the companies of unlawful behavior during recent union campaigns.

TITLE: Amazon Fires Senior Managers Tied to Unionized Staten Island Warehouse
SUMMARY: Company officials said the terminations were the result of an internal review, while the fired managers saw it as a response to the recent union victory.

TITLE: April Jobs Report: Gain of 428,000 Shows Vibrant Labor Market
SUMMARY: The Labor Department reported a gain of 428,000 jobs in April, along with a 5.5 percent increase in average hourly earnings from a year earlier.

TITLE: Biden and Harris meet with labor organizers from Amazon and Starbucks.
SUMMARY: The White House visit by rank-and-file union members was an unusual show of support by an administration of either party.

TITLE: Bank of England raises rates to 1 percent amid recession worries.
SUMMARY: The central bank predicted inflation would peak above 10 percent this year, which would be the fastest pace in four decades.

TITLE: Fed Raises Interest Rate Half a Percentage Point, Largest Increase Since 2000
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is combating the fastest price increases in four decades and is trying to cool the economy before high inflation becomes embedded.

TITLE: The Fed Wants to Fight Inflation Without a Recession. Is It Too Late?
SUMMARY: Federal Reserve officials took a while to recognize that inflation was lasting. The question is whether they can tame it gently now.

TITLE: Starbucks Plans Wage Increases That Won’t Apply to Unionized Workers
SUMMARY: The initiative was announced as labor organizers have won initial votes at more than 50 stores, including several this week.

TITLE: Job Openings in U.S. Rose to Record in March
SUMMARY: New government data suggests that the economy remains far from normal as employers struggle to fill jobs and workers seek better positions.

TITLE: The Era of Cheap and Plenty May Be Ending
SUMMARY: Supplies of goods are coming up short in the pandemic, and prices have jumped. Some economists warn that the changes could linger.

TITLE: Trade Barriers From the Ukraine War Are Sending Food Prices Higher
SUMMARY: Dozens of countries have thrown up trade barriers in the past two months to protect scarce supplies of food and commodities, but experts say the policies will only exacerbate a global food crisis.

TITLE: Fed’s Preferred Inflation Gauge Climbs 6.6% From a Year Earlier
SUMMARY: The Personal Consumption Expenditures price index climbed 6.6 percent from a year earlier, the quickest pace of increase since 1982.

TITLE: Biden Administration Plays Down Growth Decline in G.D.P. Report
SUMMARY: The administration emphasized strength in consumer spending, even as Republicans blasted its management of the economy.

TITLE: Economy Contracted in the First Quarter, but Underlying Measures Were Solid
SUMMARY: The overall figure understates the recovery because inventories needed less rebuilding and consumer spending widened the trade deficit.

TITLE: China Falls Short of Promises to Protect Intellectual Property, U.S. Says
SUMMARY: American officials said that they were monitoring China’s progress in meeting the terms of a 2020 trade deal, but that intellectual property owners had expressed concerns.

TITLE: Trump Officials Gave Pandemic Loan to Trucking Company Despite Objections
SUMMARY: A congressional report raises new questions about a pandemic relief loan to a troubled trucking company with close ties to the Trump administration.

TITLE: Senate Confirms Biden Fed Nominee, Lael Brainard, as Vice Chair
SUMMARY: Amid high inflation and global uncertainty, the Senate could soon vote on a number of nominees to the Fed.

TITLE: Hot Job Market, an Economic Relief, Is a Wall Street Worry
SUMMARY: This year’s decline in stock prices follows a historical pattern: “When unemployment is ultra low, the uppity times are behind us,” a bank research chief said.

TITLE: The prospect of lockdowns in Beijing fuels more concerns about supply chain disruptions.
SUMMARY: China’s capital city is not as central to global production networks as Shanghai, but the costs for global companies will still mount if lockdowns spread.
